description.text:
I've been using mirks Cat Food Ball, but my cat always left it where I would step on it, so I needed something sturdier.
I decided to make it one piece and add a supporting pole in the middle.
My sister said it would be the cat food ball for the next nuclear war, therefor the name "Atomic Cat Food Ball". Source moved to http://shapedo.com/telepath/atomic_cat_food_ball

• Should be printed with external support (no internal support!), although it looked like it might work even without.
  • You might try using Jitter, because otherwise internal threads might block on side where you cannot remove them easily from the outside.
  • After printig, fill it with cat food (the dry sort, doh)
  • Have fun the next few weeks teaching your cat how to get the food out!

comments.text: I switched to Slic3r, which doesn't support exterior-only support, so I'm testing it with "Enforce support for the first: 20 layers" set. This should have the same effect.

description.text: have fun.

This is a badge based on the Fallout 4 load screen pins. Attach a pin to the back to wear!
Please let me know if there are any issues so that I may fix them.

As for the artwork original artwork © 2016 Bethesda Softworks LLC, a ZeniMax Media company.

LHCP 5.8gHz Rx/Tx antenna for FPV. Looks like an Airblade by IBCrazy. Performance depends fully on your building skills.

Apperently flipping the STL along the X axis in Sli3r is too much of a challenge, so I did it for you. Added RHCP_Gig.stl.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

To complete the build you need:
five M3x5 button head hex screws (for the jig)
Print the parts and clean them up. Cut M3 threads into the five holes on the jig.

Antenna is tuned to 5780hz, left hand circular polarized (LHCP). To make a RHCP antenna, simply flip the jig around the Y axis in sli3r (no I will not do that for you).

I created this jig because a set of IBCrazy Airblades costing $64.99 will end up costing $120.- when factoring in shipping, tax and Danish Postal Services handling fee.

To make a set of antennas:
RG402 semi-ridgid coax cable
SMA or RP-SMA connector (the solder on type)
0.8mm MiG welding wire
6mm and 8mm heat shrink
Epoxy putty to secure the center of the antennas once finished

Using the bending tool, cut five pieces of 0.8mm MiG welding wire to 65mm (4x13mm + 4x0.8mm bends + 10mm peg).
Use a set of needle nose pliers and the bending tool to bend 5 square lobes with a 10mm peg at the end. Angle the peg so it fits into the center piece. About a 55 degree angle. Secure the lobes with the M3x5 screws. Bend the tips of the lobe wires to meet in the middle. Remove the center piece and insert the RG402 coax (about 3mm of the outer braid removed). Solder the center core to the lobe tips, then solder the lobe pegs to the outer braid of the RG402. Make sure that inner and outer part of the RG402 does not touch. Add a piece of heat shrink to the antenna and solder the balun in place. Secure with another piece of heat shrink or epoxy putty.

Use the bending tool to mark a 26mm section of wire to use as a balun (½ wavelength). Bend the wire around a 6mm rod to create a small spiral and cut the balun where marked.

Andrew McNeil explains how to use a balun here: https://youtu.be/InLEq04R5So?t=9m58s
Watch this video to get the general idea of how to use a antenna jig: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PKhqbBy2ls

[DISCLAIMER]
I will not alter the files to accommodate your specific printer/slicing software or what ever size wire you have in stock. I will not provide test data or proof of concept. If you want to make one, make one. IF they work for you, great. If not, buy a set of Airblade antennas from IBCrazy, I hear they are awesome :-)

You may not under any circumstances use this jig to produce antennas intended for sale. Please support Alex Greve aka. IBCrazy by buying his antennas instead. A lot of time and money has gone into the creation of his antennas.

comments.text: I am actually trying to hook up a 4 start 1/4-16 acme lead screw. I don't have too much trouble with layers though since i fixed the firmware flaw where they rounded up. also it helps to check your slicing height for your lead screw on http://calculator.josefprusa.cz/http://calculator.josefprusa.c... this way your stepper motor completes a full step instead of having the gcode try and make the stepper motor make a partial step which it wont. the firmware mistake and not setting the correct layer height are some of the major causes for the banding everyone chases to fix thinking its leadscrew backlash, that and calibrating the feed of the filament.
comments.author: BlackestofOz

comments.text: As for the firmware I'd already taken into account their oversight on rounding off decimal places on the z axis default steps. For a SD user that should go without saying. And yes, I do make sure my stepper makes one rev every layer. I was discussing mechanical changes your making...
comments.author: BV3D

comments.text: ya metric lead screw would be better dont  really have many issues and its easy to use whats available at my local hardware store. ill look into using metric lead screws on my printers when i release later this year. 12"x12"12" 2 color printer with lcd all standard for less than $2,000.00

title: Two part Naruto kunai knife (toy)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kunai knife is a popular throwing and hand-to-hand knife in Naruto. I wanted to make few as props but existing ones on Thingiverse were made of very many parts so I designed a two part model in Solidworks. It can be printed without supports and the two parts have large interconnecting area where plastic glue does its job well.

Sand paper or cut the sharp edge (when slicing) to your liking for safety! After printing and attaching the parts the handle can be covered with white tape or perhaps white linen glued onto it.

This was my first own sketch for a 3D printer from over a year back but I decided to add it now because it has been useful as a prop.

Troublemaker v2 3D printer is an improved version of Troublemaker, a derivative from the highly popular open-source 3D printer Ultimaker Original. A DIY friendly open-source release together with a complete kit of assembly parts, CAD files and technical documentation is available also on Github.

SPECIFICATIONS:

PRINTING SPECIFICATIONS
Build volume (mm): 300 X 300 X 300
Auto levelling: Optional
Minimal layer height (mm): 0.05
Steps/mm (X & Y): 80
HotEnd: 1 X E3D-V6 1.75 mm (swappable with any E3D)
Travel speed (mm/s): 200
Print speed (mm/s): 150
Heated bed: Yes - 24V or 230V

MECHANICAL SPECIFICATIONS
Desktop size (mm): 460 X 440 X 660
Frame: Plywood
Linear rails: 8 mm ground hardened steel

ELECTRICAL SPECIFICATIONS
Supply Voltage (V AC): 240 or 110
Supply connection: Switched and fused IEC Socket. Lead not provided.
Power supply: 1 X 24V 100W / 1 X 24V 350W (if 24V bed)
Electronics control board: RUMBA + LCD
Motor drivers: 4 X DRV8825 (X,Y,Z,E)
Motors: X: 46 Ncm 1.8° / Y: 46 Ncm 1.8° / Z: 46 Ncm 1.8°

SOFTWARE SPECIFICATIONS
Recommended slicing software: CURA / Slic3r

BUILD TIME
From full-kit: 12h

title: MakerBot pen holder (1 piece)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pen holder for the MakerBot. I did this new design, although there already exists at least one other pen holder design on thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790). The main difference: It's only one simple part. There are two stl files:
  • Stifthalter_1part.stl: This contains the part layed out at a 45Â° angle. That way it easily fits on the MakerBot build platform. This file is best printed without a raft.
  • Stifthalter_1part_horizontal.stl: The same object but layed out at 90Â°. That way a raft would be much smaller, but the object uses almost the complete width of the build platform...

• Print the part
  • Insert a pen
  • If necessary, use a M3 bolt/nut to tighten the clamp
  • Attach the whole thing to the MakerBot Z stage with two M5 bolt (same bolts as used to attach the dinos).

Hello There this is my First upload to Thingiverse. It is a USB Case in the Shape of a Key Hope you like it. I printed it with a 10% infill and Stranded Speed.

My new toy is the V912 from WLToys. A nice 4 axis RC helicopter 40cm main rotor diameter fixed pitch.
I looked for the best way to print blades (I don't yet break one but the question is not "if" but "when" I'll break one!) There is here 3 versions of blade:
the original is almost the same of original one ;)
the two other are some research for more "silent" blade.
The small one need more rotor speed => more stability with the bell bar (gyroscopic effect) => less flight time because of overconsumption. Good for small indore place to flight or windy conditions outside. The second one is abound the same lift force of the original one and a little bit more silent...
(... Ok, I don't realy scientifically measure it but, you know... it's my baby and it's the best :P ) And of cours, it flight!!
http://youtu.be/0OCL_kJv0hk The 3D printed cannopy is another work in progress, still with the vase technic but only 1 shell ultra light printing... I'll tell you more soon ;) EDIT: Original improves is the last design. The "silent"one seems to be unstable, so I redesigne a smooth shape with same caracteristics of the original.

The best way I found to print a plade is to use the "perimeter only" methode, with the blade placed vertically on the edge, just like a vase.
There is a lots of work with dremel and sand paper after, and a little drill. but the results is amazingly good and the weight is only 1grame more of the original blade. So I print it with 0%infile, 3 shell and 0.25 height. Good flights!!

title: Ultimaker E3Dv6 mount with inductive/capacitive sensor

description.text:
This is my version for an Ultimaker E3D mount. It alows the use of a 12mm diameter capacitive/inductive sensor.

Extra parts needed:

  • 2x LM6UU-38mm linear bearings
  • 1x M3x25 screws
  • 1x M3x10 screw
  • 2x M3 nuts
  • 2x 30mm fan (and their screws) (may fit bigger fans with included adapter)

(the photo is from a previous version, but quite a similar one)
The design includes for sure remixes from other parts taken from here and there. Although it's reworked from scratch, it's mainly based in the design of am001 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94678), if you can find any other influence, then, just tell me and I'll be editing this and will be happy to add the credits as needed.

Any questions, please post on here. Have fun!

Printer:

i3BOXed

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print all parts in ABS, support is needed in some of them,

Some captive nuts and screws may be difficult to insert, sockets need to be thoroughfully cleaned.
Check the fit of screws from the fans before assembling, they are intended to be near M3, but I can't seem to find two identical fans so I use whatever screw suits...

You can route the wiring (thermistor, heater, fans and switch) up throgh the tube and secure them with zipties, and use a cable sleeve to get a neat finish.

Needed some end-stop switches for my DIY dremel-cnc, and couldn't find any that worked for me. so I made this :)

If there is interest, I might add a body-part to make it be "always on" by default, like a normal micro-switch. Comment if you want me to...

  • Screws: M3x20mm (4x)
  • Nuts: M3 (5x)
  • Washers: M3 (7x)
  • Two wires

1 of every part, except 2 of box_body.stl

Bed: 70C

Step one: filing

Used a round file and a flat file to make all holes smooth, so that screws didn't bind. Especially important on box_lid

Step two: assembling box_bottom
  • Press fit one of thee washers into the recess in the part.
  • take one of your wires, take off some insulation and twist the end (5mm)
thread end of wire down into hole and press it into slot (slot has been widened since photo) put another washer on a screw, and thread into hole, capturing end of wire. add washer and nut on the other side and tighten. Step 3: Assembling box_lid and cap
  • thread a nut onto screw (this is for adding adjustment and because my screws are a bit long)
  • put screw through hole in box_lid
  • put spring onto screw/box_lid
  • put cap_plate onto screw, so that the knobby part holds the spring.
  • put a washer on the screw
  • thread second wire through hole in cap_hood (widen if required)
  • fasten wire end to a washer, and put it on the screw as well
  • add nut and tighten till screw is flush
  • push cap_hood onto cap_plate, while pulling on wire so it goes on with no wire left inside (might want to use pliers for this)
Step3: Assemble body

This is the easy part.

  • Thread two screws thorugh lid, both body parts, and thorugh bottom.
  • Add washers and nuts
  • Done!
Step 4: mount

I mounted mine using the long screw that goes thorugh the bottom. You can also mount using the other two screws, glue, or make a custom mount with your printer

using the screw makes it easy to adjust the trigger spot.

title: Extensible filament holder for 6mm acrylic frame

description.text:
I don´t like the way the Sunhokey 3d printer deal with the filament spool, so i did a easy holder...

I designed it in two pieces, so you can use the 2 cm extra if you change the position of the smal piece so it can fit in the maain piece bolt hole.
It fits with the holes that Sunhokey uses to hold the lcd frame, i prefer to use them for this than for the weak lcd connection...
It uses a couple of M3 20mm bolts/nuts.

A couple of warnings, the 6mm acrylic frame doesn´t seems to hold a great weight without crack, so please try and see your spool when you put it before first use.

The other is that this holder is not compatible with high printings, The spool goes down to the printer and can touch tour piece if it is too tall. It doesn´t interrupt the x-carriage movement (See the pics)

description.text:
This is a "Stitch Bow" floss holder used to store and preserve floss for embroidery. One floss holder can hold a single skein of floss from common vendors like DMC. This model is made to blend in with your other holders. If you want them to stand out, I suggest printing them in many colors!

Notes:

This model prints very easily in PLA or ABS. I print these in PLA on cold blue tape with no problems. They take 20 minutes or less to print, half that time on a delta or high quality machine.

The 3D printed version may have sharper edges than the original object, and the small ridges at the ends are only on one side. If this matters to you, you can round off sharp edges with an xacto-knife or small file.

OpenSCAD makes it easy

This model was built in OpenSCAD and the source code is included. You can adjust the parameters at the top of the file to make holders of different sizes. Make them shorter or longer with bar_len, wider or narrower with bar_width, and thicker, and thinner with thickness. If you prefer to have a hole on the label part, you can add one by changing the hole diameter label_hole_d.

The goal of this project, started in Spring 2015, was to create a cheap and lightweight extruder, the first choose was "24BYJ48", substituted with "28BYJ-48" (Fig.1) because stronger, cheaper and easy to find.
This stepper motor is unipolar and it needs to be modified to become bipolar, there are 2 methods: the first method consists by unmounting the case (Fig.2). the second consists, in a faster and less invasive method, by cutting the plastic case and PCB, i suggest this method (Fig.3).

You need:
x2 - 28BYJ-48
x2 - 40mm fans
x4 - M3 screws + nuts
x4 - M4 30mm screws + nuts
x5 - M4 20mm screws + nuts
x2 - MK8 drive gear for 1,75 mm filament
x2 - 605 2RS 5X14X5 bearings
x? - M4 washers
The connection to RAMP 1.4 must be modified (Fig.4), the connector of second extruder is inverted connected

Assembly: (Fig.5)
(Tolerance is always 0,5mm excluding Hot-Ends connectors)
Idlers are different and they are marked with L or R letters visible in the model, the washer is used to centering the bearing with drive gear (fig.6).
Hot-Ends connectors dimensions are copied from Greg Wade's extruder, their distance is 23mm.

How to use it:
This motor is slower, fragile and weak compared to NEMA17, plastic gears inside it can be easily damaged, so the Hot-End temperature must be increased to soften more the filament (in my tests i use PLA at 210-220°c), maybe the print speed will need to be slower, another problem with this motor is the pression of idler, if less the filament is not pulled into Hot-End, if too much the motor don't go, you have to find the right distance, i suggest to add washers at idler regulating screw to fix at the right distance you found, so u don't need to find the right distance everytime(Fig.7).
Top fan is needed because the motors overheat fast, motors drivers power should decreased because these motors need less power then NEMA17.

Settings:
Steps per mm are ~1500
Max speed is ~8mm/s

Problem/Solution:
The motor don't works: wrong wiring, filament idler pressure is too much, speed is too fast, driver power is too low, it's broken.
No filament extrusion: filament idler pressure is too much or less, Hot-End temperature too low.
Filament extrusion is unstable or stops after a while: filament idler pressure is too much.
Layers are not uniform/bad looking object: try to increase temperature(Fig.8).

I made this 3D printer in Spring-Summer 2015, the main feature of this project is its anti-wobble system, it consists in the separation of Y and Z axis from Z screws, Y axis can moves freely on Z axis, because it's leaning on Z screws.
This innovation avoids the transmission of Z screws wobble to Z axis.
This printer has no XZ dimension limits (X structure limits Y dimension to 20cm, it's poorly designed ).
Extruder mount can be replaced with a PRUSA
(Tolerance is always 0,5mm)

title: Maze and Puzzle: Taiwan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The combination of maze and puzzle is just like the current state of Taiwan. When will it go out of the maze? When will the puzzle be completed?

"Maze and Puzzle: Taiwan" is based on the Puzzle generator and Random maze generator. Everytime you run the customizer, a different maze would be generated.

Parameters:

  • width
  • maze_x_blocks
  • puzzle_x_blocks
  • ditch_width
  • spacing

The size of Taiwan is 100 x 150. In other words, it has a ratio of 2:3. In order to generate a maze or a puzzle which matches Taiwan, the value of maze_x_blocks or puzzle_x_blocks should be a multiple of 2.

Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

Find all my puzzles in puzzles collection.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.

  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

It's not that easy to find a solution to make sure the filament doesn't get stuck during a print. After hours of browsing thingiverse, failing with a couple of spool holder designs and a ton of canceled prints because of filaments knots I started from scratch and came up with a new approach: the filament duck ("inspired" by a duckbill).
  • no fiddling around on the back of the printer
  • easy to use
  • great form factor
  • no supports
  • no assembly
  • no extra parts

I used the low quality profile (3h). I recommend to use helper disks (in MakerWare: File -> Examples -> Helper Disks) or even a raft to ensure that the first layers don't raise from the bulding plate during printing. If that happens the product will be usable as well but the stand won't be even. The model has little holes for use with small rubber feet for secure standing.

title: Gopro Hero 3 (only 3) camera box for the Ritewing Zephyr 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Box replaces Zephyr II nose so you have a protected environment for the camera to film, the collar is optional, it will block the view if you set it to wide-angle, medium angle is fine though.
The camera plate is a universal plate for small FPV camera's, supports every lens and quick lens change, locks in place with 2 tie wraps. Warning: This has been untested, i haven't put it on my Zephyr yet!
Warning 2: sand the inside before you put a gopro in, it's gonna scratch the casing
Warning 3: I print everything with a 0.32 JHead nozzle, your mileage may vary! Coming soon: battery box

Print the box, sand inside, optionally glue the collar on (U side up) and put the gopro down with a tiewrap.  
Uhu-por glue sticks to PLA like sh#t to a blanket, use that!

comments.text: I printed one with a Da Vinci 1.0 in ABS. I managed to get the go pro in but had to break the part to get it back out. I would have had to do a lot of sanding to get it to fit correctly. I think it would be better to be just a tad oversized and then use a rubber band to hold it in place.
comments.author: carrera0to60

comments.text:
That's true, I wanted to do that but due to some issues I haven't gotten round to it yet. Unfortunately, my hard drive crashed and I lost the source file for this. If your printer prints perfectly it should fit right in though.
I recently crashed my Z and this box is mangled, I'll have to redo it to see if I can make a better version that is compatible with rubber bands.

We wanted to make some cookies and shape them like musical symbols, so here we are.

After a few all-in-one iterations, we finally settled on one part to cut the cookie shape and another to imprint the design on the cut cookie. This gives the cook some control in how thick the dough is rolled and how much the design is pushed into the cut shape.

comments.text: I was about to suggest making notes to go with these, but then found http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:600957
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: The font I was using, Bravura, makes it a piece of cake to create clefs and a multitude of musical notation, but notes are a bit of a pain. Essentially it breaks a note down to a blob, a stem, and any number of tails, together with dots and stress marks and so on and so forth. Initially I intended to set up some notes, so I may take another stab at it. I quite like the idea of the outer cookie shape together with a strong emboss of the design. I also did a search before bothering to create them from scratch, but could find something quite how I wanted it.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Hmm why can't you though? I mean scaling up is simple, or is it a problem with the proportions?
comments.author: Cheesywafflefries

comments.text: I'd like to use this for something like Frostgrave; It'd be easier to scale up if the model could be split apart easily; i.e. turret, bridge, buildings... as it is the model is one mesh blob.  After a quick rescale and size comparison with some other 28mm building models, the final size of this object would be near 700mm x 357mm x 400mm - way too large for my little printer, lol.  I guess it could be split further with hard line splices but it would take about 6-8 individual "blocks" that would need to be printed out separately and then glued together.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eCLUfF2HlDw

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eSDkyJnjuno
I created this design for my sister, I had the Pololu Round Robot Chassis Kit so I created all the parts according to it. I created different versions of stl files, some have holes for sensors, it depends by what you want to create. I ordered ultrasonic sensor to avoid impacts, bluetooth module to control R2D2 with my smartphone. (Online there are many apps, I have still to decide which one I can use). The head has a hole for the led. The base has a hole for an on/off switch. I ordered a servo to move the head (but I have to test it, probably servo isn't enough) I will use a module and a speaker to make it talk. Most of modules are in travel to my house so I will keep updating this post. If you have any sugguestions or questions feel free to write me. :)
P.s.
I used adhesive paper to finish the details of R2D2 so I added the stencils to make some details.

Bill of materials

-Robot Chassis Kit ( http://www.robotshop.com/en/pololu-round-robot-chassis-kit-solid-blue.html)
-Arduino(Uno is enough, Mega is ok)
-H bridge(http://www.ebay.it/itm/181855403486?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

  • 1 led RGB common catode(http://www.ebay.it/itm/10-LED-RGB-4-PIN-Catodo-Comune-5mm-Ultrabrillante-10-RGB-LED-COMMON-CHATODE-/131167077543?hash=item1e8a2ac4a7:g:y1IAAOxyBjBTTB5n)

    -1 switch on/off (http://www.ebay.it/itm/Pulsante-Interruttore-ON-OFF-2-Pin-6A-250V-SWITCH-ROCKER-/172113140757?hash=item2812be1c15:g:zREAAOSwY45UTjo5)
    -1 power bank (10000 mAh is ok)
    -1 breadboard
    -ultrasonic sensor for arduino (http://www.ebay.it/itm/New-Arduino-Ultrasonic-Module-HC-SR04-Distance-Sensor-Measuring-Transducer-LS-/161937960004?hash=item25b4412c44:g:L0gAAOSwYIhWi4Zg)

comments.author: 3asd

comments.text:
devi fare riferimento al wiki di grbl. Devi modificare gli steps/mm qui: https://github.com/gnea/grbl/wiki/Grbl-v1.1-Configuration
ecco i comandi che ti interessano:
$100, $101 and $102 – [X,Y,Z] steps/mm
Grbl needs to know how far each step will take the tool in reality. To calculate steps/mm for an axis of your machine you need to know:
The mm traveled per revolution of your stepper motor. This is dependent on your belt drive gears or lead screw pitch.
The full steps per revolution of your steppers (typically 200)
The microsteps per step of your controller (typically 1, 2, 4, 8, or 16). Tip: Using high microstep values (e.g., 16) can reduce your stepper motor torque, so use the lowest that gives you the desired axis resolution and comfortable running properties.
The steps/mm can then be calculated like this: steps_per_mm = (steps_per_revolution*microsteps)/mm_per_rev
Compute this value for every axis and write these settings to Grbl.

This is Communicator Badge as seen on Star Trek: The Next Generation. I designed it based on the official resin model. The new "thick" version is slightly redesigned to be more accurate to the real prop.  
I find this to be an excellent calibration object because it is small, prints quickly, but has a unique shape that is tricky to print if the machine is not calibrated properly.

Paint the round part gold, the delta silver, and outline the edges of the delta in black.
Glue a pin or velcro to the back and you've got a great addition to a uniform or just something to wear to show you're a Trekkie.

Metronome Engine.
I wanted to build a test rig to check some calculations I made to determine the dimensions for a compound pendulum , these had been done in Excel and were intended for a new wooden clock design I was working on. I had based the rig design on the engine used in a metronome. It's the only mechanism that I could find that actually used the compound pendulum so it turned out to be ideal for 3D printing. The rig is driven by a weight inside the steam engine style boiler on the end of a stalk, it drives an escape wheel through a gravity ratchet and a couple of gears to give around 2.5 minutes of running time. The compound pendulum controls the rate at which it tick-tocks. Moving the top weight up slows down the pendulum and visa verse. The top and bottom weights can also be changed out for bigger or smaller weights to also change the rate. With all these possible variations it was straight forward to finesse the results to get the right combination that could be scaled up for use in a larger wooden clock.
This rig could also be modified to add a scale so that it could be used as a metronome, as it is it's actually a nice little gadget to create on your 3D printer.

You will need 1 of each STL part except for the following:-
Spacer 3 requires 2 parts
Pawl requires 4 parts
Wedge requires 3 parts
Escapement requires 2 parts to be solvent bonded back to back

You will need some extra components to complete the build :-
6 roller bearings Ø2mm x Ø6mm x 3mm
1 piece Ø1.5mm steel rod for the pendulum
1 piece Ø2mm steel rod for the pendulum pivot
2 piece Ø2mm steel rod for the gear shafts
Acetone to solvent bond the frame and other parts together.
Ø9.5mm steel balls (Catapult ammo) for the weight.
Ø12mm Brass rod for the weights Or washers, 8 grams for top weight and 23 grams for the bottom weight.
Magnet Ø5 x 5mm long to hold the top pendulum weight in position.

STL files for download are in 3 groups Blue, Red, and Orange, Use the drawing as a guide for where the components fit into the assembly.

For more detail go to http://www.3dprinterclocks.com/page19.html.

View a video of the working rig here https://youtu.be/jI1B_eK7I_Q

STL files are grouped in the 3 ZIP files.

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

Medium

Notes:

Most of the parts can be positioned so that supports are unnecessary, but some will need it.
Generally the infill is medium but most of the small parts would benefit from a denser infill.

Drilling the gears.

The gears and spacers mounted on the cross shafts will need to be a loose fit on the shafts so should be drilled out to Ø2,5mm. The T-connector and the Escapement, however, need to be a tight fit on their respective shafts. There is a small magnet fitted to the top pendulum weight support that will grip on the Pendulum shaft so that it will stay in place until moved by hand.
The Escapements will probably need a little tweaking to get it to work properly, slight adjustments with a file should suffice.

I bought a dremel drill stand a while ago to use to drill the tiny little holes in the PCBs that I made, but as anyone with one of them knows, there's no light on it, so it's hard to see where your drilling without pushing a lamp or something next to it. After a while of the lamp not being in the right place to see, or it falling over, I designed this and printed it out.  
It slips right over the back rod of the drill stand and is slightly larger than the rod/tube so it can be slid over the couplings, so just screw a large bolt into it and it'll stay attached.  
I know it looks like the green lantern ring symbol :P But just print it out, drill a big hole in the front of it where the bar up and down is, and put a bolt in there, drill it slightly smaller than the large bolt so it grabs the threads with the plastic really well, and on the sides, just drill out the holes needed to put whatever you want on it.  
I put a 4 AA battery pack on one side, and a 5v regulator attached to a usb port that I made ages ago, but didnt have a use for, and had this usb keyboard light for seeing the keyboard in the dark I think, but never used it. The usb light has one of the bendable necks on it and is fairly long, so you can move it wherever you wanted.
Small model of my printrbot play that I keep on my desk at work :)

title: Pico projector adjustable mount and frame holder

description.text: To test some design concepts at work, I needed to build a tripod-mounted bar to hold a pico projector and a foam-core "frame" in a way that both were adjustable. When I was at the hardware store to buy the pieces to make the bar, I found these long wooden pieces that were exactly the shape of track I was going to build. Since they were laying behind the large saw they use to cut wood for customers, I asked what they were and discovered they were the pieces that hold the plastic strapping on the outside of the palettes of wood they get. The nice gentleman then said "you can just have one". Perfect! He told me to tell the checkout person it was a "runner". I don't know if that is a generic term for "free wood" or the actual technical name. Either way it was free which was awesome. These pieces are probably of limited value as usable pieces (unless you have a "runner" and a pico projector and frame that need to be adjustable), but may be interesting for learning from or improving upon. More back-story, discoveries, and pictures at my blog: Part 1: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-14 Part 2: http://wp.me/p2hTaI-Q

I had problems slicing the plate of all three pieces, so I split each out into their own STL files. I included the plate just in case (but I wouldn't use it).
Print one of each (or just the plate of all three) and assemble by sliding the "top" into the "endcap" and fastening with a #8 bolt and wing-nut. The hole in the "top" piece is what attaches to the pico projector's tripod mount hole with a 1/4-20 screw (standard tripod screw) and E-clip to hold it in-place.
On the "frame holder" there are three holes for #8 bolts and wing-nuts; use as many to hold a frame as needed (I used one for a lightweight foam-core frame)

description.text:
This mount, in conjunction with some good double sided tape, allows you to mount your action camera (I'm using a Mobius and Foxeer Legend1) at a 20° angle at the cost of some battery tray space. With the camera moved back, and the back slung low, the camera is less likely to get hit in a crash, and the overall profile of the quad is smaller compared to a traditional angled mount using the front plate, reducing drag by a fair bit. And isn't low profile why we run 210mm quads in the first place? The weight balance is perfect with a 1300, but anything longer than that will make it a little tail heavy.

Note - I threw some 0.3mm tall circles at the base of this design to provide better bed adhesion. They're pretty easy to remove post print, for those wondering.
Just button of ABS plastic
